article.title: Young, metal-enriched cores in early-type dwarf galaxies in the Virgo cluster based on colour gradients

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the radial color profile of galaxy VCC 1501 in g-r and i-H. What information can be obtained from the slopes of the fitted lines?
choices: The galaxy\'s color gradient, indicating potential age and metallicity variations.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the i-H and g-r color gradients for a sample of galaxies. What is the significance of the galaxies located above the black horizontal tick mark?
choices: They are classified as non-dwarf galaxies.
They have experienced recent mergers with smaller galaxies.
They exhibit blue cores, indicating younger stellar populations in their centers.
They are located in the outskirts of the Virgo cluster.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents histograms of residual colors and i-H gradients for different g-r gradient quartiles. What key trend is observed regarding blue-cored early-type dwarfs?
choices: They tend to have redder g-r and i-H colors.
They exhibit a wide range of i-H gradients.
They show a strong correlation between age color and i-H gradient.
They typically have bluer g-r and i-H colors, particularly at the effective radius.

multiple_choice_question.text: This equation represents the simplified age color: [(g-r) - 0.3(i-H)].  Why is this calculation useful for analyzing stellar populations?
choices: It accurately predicts the exact age of individual stars in a galaxy.
It isolates the age-related color component, minimizing the influence of metallicity.
It determines the galaxy\'s distance from Earth based on color redshift.
It calculates the total mass of the galaxy based on color and luminosity.
